did.unittitle: Court of Quarter Sessions, Chester County, PA records

bioghist.p: Includes records of the Clerk of Courts of Quarter Sessions and Oyer and Terminer and General Jail Delivery and Criminal Rcords of the Sheriff. The Chester County Court of Quarter Sessions heard criminal cases and dealt with county administrative matters. This court was based on English practice and was shaped by the laws passed by Pennsylvania’s General Assembly. The early county court held by justices of the peace heard all types of cases (civil, criminal, estate) and dealt with administrative functions such as levying taxes, controlling finances, caring for the poor, overseeing building of roads and bridges, and laying out townships and boroughs. The judicial system of Pennsylvania was reorganized by the “Ordinance for Establishing of Courts” (1707). The ordinance designated the provincial court the “supreme court” and formally divided the county court into criminal and civil courts: the court of quarter sessions and the court of common pleas respectively. The Pennsylvania Constitution of 1969 brought about significant changes in the structure of the court of quarter sessions as it abolished the courts of oyer and terminer and general jail delivery, quarter sessions of the peace and orphans’ court: the jurisdiction of these courts was transferred to the court of common pleas. In Chester County, criminal records continue to be maintained by the clerk of courts.

scopecontent.p: Includes dockets and books, indexes to dockets and book, and papers. Types of records include but are not limited to: indictments, tavern license papers, indentured servant and apprentice records, reports of directors of the poor, licenses for hawkers, peddlers and Indian traders. Topics : economics, labor, law, government, crime, poverty, women, and social and local history. Records are housed at Chester County Archives & Record Services, Govt. Services Center, 601 Westtown Road, West Chester, PA 19380. 610-344-6760. The Chester County Archives is administered by the Chester County Historical Society in cooperation with the County of Chester.
